content: The only MSFs I know of are Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF) and the index file Thunderbird uses to store a list of email in a folder (not the emails, just the list). As this is regenerated automatically if it is missing, Why would you be seeking that?

content:
That I suspect is the work of your antivirus program. Something interrupted the file writes hence the oddball numbers on the end. You need an exception in your antivirus program for the Thunderbird profile folders. See https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/profiles-where-thunderbird-stores-user-data

This is a bit of open heart surgery, so please make a copy of your Thunderbird profile folders and contents before you take any actions.

Go to the troubleshooting information on the help menu. Click on the show profile button in the first block of information (it is about 3/4 of the way does the visible page usually) Close Thunderbird. Backup the folder that was opened in the windows file manager and it's sub folders. If something goes wrong there will then be a way back.

Open the mail folder and then the "local folder" folder Under that you will see the trash and the two X and Z folder will be in that folder with files of the names shown in the trash folder of Thunderbird. So you may see for example xxz.sdb xxz.msf or xxz with no file extension. all are valid for different stated of the folder or the folder having sub folders. What is important here is to delete them. Everything in the trash folder can be deleted, I would think as you do not mention the folder having anything in it you need to keep. But you can delete individual file/folder sets if that makes you more comfortable.

Restart Thunderbird and I hope everything is gone, if not close Thunderbird, open the profile folder again and delete the file foldertree and restart Thunderbird. That will force a full rebuild of the folder pane in Thunderbird. It should happen automatically after the files are deleted, but I have heard stories of it having to be deleted as well to show the change. But please get your self that exception setup. It will greatly reduce the issues going forward in my opinion.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: Why would you want to recreate your account in Thunderbird after changing the password. That makes not real sense at all. So why are you trying to add it again? and why are you changing your password? what was the prompt for that. Both are valid questions as changing of a password is not something that has anything to do with Thunderbird, but many folk do that when they experience an issue because they get some dialog about wanting a password so it is easier to ask than assume.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
That sounds to me like the email is actually malformed.

Open the message source (CTRL+U) it should contain in the header a field designated From: what is showing in there in the message source?
